description: Triangle in which first row is 1, n-th row (n>1) gives prime factors of n with repetition.
links: N. J. A. Sloane, First 2048 rows of triangle, flattened
S. von Worley (?), Animated Factorization Diagrams, Oct. 2012.
maple: P:=proc(n) local FM: FM:=ifactors(n)[2]: seq(seq(FM[j][1],k=1..FM[j][2]),j=1..nops(FM)) end: 1; for n from 2 to 45 do P(n) od; # yields sequence in triangular form; _Emeric Deutsch_, Feb 13 2005
mathematica: row[n_] := Flatten[ Table[#[[1]], {#[[2]]}] & /@ FactorInteger[n]]; Flatten[ Table[ row[n], {n, 1, 45}]] (* _Jean-FranÃ§ois Alcover_, Dec 01 2011 *)
prog: (Haskell)import Data.List (unfoldr)a027746 n k = a027746_tabl !! (n-1) !! (k-1)a027746_tabl = map a027746_row [1..]a027746_row 1 = [1]a027746_row n = unfoldr fact n where   fact 1 = Nothing   fact x = Just (p, x `div` p) where p = a020639 x-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Aug 27 2011(PARI) A027746_row(n,o=[1])=if(n>1,concat(apply(t->vector(t[2],i,t[1]),Vec(factor(n)~))),o) \\ Use %(n,[]) if you want the more natural [] for the first row. - _M. F. Hasler_, Jul 29 2015
crossrefs: Cf. A175943 (partial products), A265110 (partial row products), A265111.
author: _Maghraoui Abdelkader_
